title: Requesting Critique
content:
It has been a while since posting about my project, and as it's still in progress and today is my birthday, I figure it's as good a time as any to post an update.
But more importantly, I want to ask for constructive criticism from anyone and everyone. So to get to the good stuff, here's a download:

[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/keentechdemo10.zip]Commander Keen Technology Demo[/url]

If you don't want to go through the readme file, here are the controls:
Arrows for movement.
Left Ctrl - Jump
Left Alt - Pogo
Space - Shoot
Square brackets [ ] - Change weapon
Pause - Pause
Escape - Quit and Close
In case you get stuck (it is a tech demo), press Left-Shift + A + Left-Control all together to reset your location.

Because it is amusing, you might want to try pressing page down a couple times and then running around, shooting and such. And try mixing this with page-up... you'll see. Press pause a couple times to reset the timing.

On to the important stuff...
Please tell me what you think about things I need to change.
To get it started, I'm not yet satisfied with the jumping/pogoing height. Also there are a couple bugs involving jumping and hitting a ceiling or landing on a moving platform. Nothing that crashes the game, just bugs in how the game behaves.
The score area at the top is not close to being finished, that area will also include at least one "energy" bar. Possibly two, if I use an energy meter instead of the one-hit-kill of original Keen games. If there are extra lives, those will be displayed there too.

And there are a few specific questions:
1. Weapon display. Should it hide the way it does, always stay visible, or hide another way?
2. Weapon display. Is it visible enough, or too hard to see? I don't want to do any alpha-blending because that takes a significant amount of CPU time and I want this to run on semi-older PCs.
3. Point and Weapon items. Should they move around like the weapon pickups in this demo, or remain still like the points? In the original games, items are still, though animated, but I think the movement looks nifty. Perhaps it is too much activity?
4. Weapon items. In this game, you will always have all the weapons in your inventory, but will need amunition for them. (Just like the original Keens, you don't need to go find a weapon to use it.) In the original games, the ammunition pickup looked like the gun instead of ammo, but I like the way the purple slime balls look in my demo. However, would these be too easily confused with point items?

(edited - added Escape to controls.)

title: Re: Requesting Critique
content:
Freezing:
I'm sorry, big mistake on my part. One of the things I have not worked on is allowing you to switch between this game and other programs. If you alt-tab to another program, and then come back, it will stall the game with a black screen. Press escape to quit.

The Red #:
In a literal sense, this is how many times the engine draws a frame per second. However, it will never get a very high number. What the engine does is completely renders a frame, and then waits until the screen is redrawing to send that frame to the screen. So this number is directly affected by your monitor's refresh rate. (Typically 60 to 85 Hertz - or 60 to 85 frames per second.) So if the engine has to do the same amount of processing for each frame, the red number is going to stay pretty close to the refresh rate, or half of it. (Or a quarter.)

FPS:
Thanks to you guys pointing out that it is running slowly, I went back and noticed one REALLY simple optimization I put off a while ago and forgot about. Basically, this allows the engine to take a shortcut on something it has to do a lot for each frame, and then find out if it has to go back and take the long route. It may not sound that great, but I did some simple tests to see if it would have any affect, and it only needs to take the long route less than 4 times out of 100. (So it could be a pretty big improvement!)

Pogo, Jump, and Walk speed:
Thanks, in your opinion, how would you say they should be adjusted. Slow down the pogo and jump? Speed up the walk? Or both?

Movement when pogoing:
Thanks for catching this, for some reason I didn't notice. I was supposed to change the motion effect when jumping or pogoing, so it doesn't operate the same as when walking. When walking, pressing an arrow directly affects the players velocity. But when in the air, it should affect the players acceleration.

Graphics Library:
DirectDraw. So DirectX. I think it requires at least DX6, but possibly 7, although I've tried to make sure I use only things available in 6. DirectX 9 requires at least Win 98, I suppose that's not such a bad requirement, but if I can keep it in DX7, it will work on Win 95. (Of course, if the game gets too complex, it may not perform playable on a computer running Win 95...)
Although I do a lot of work in C#, this game is written in C++.

I've fixed the "sticking to ceiling" problem. And after looking for more simple optimizations, I'll post an updated exe later today.

title: Re: Requesting Critique
content:
Thanks a ton, Allstories!
Upon further review, the call on the field ... wait a sec, I mean upon further review (due to your result), I've found that the engine is actually strangely slow on certain machines.
Although I'm not certain, I think the difference in machines is because of something in the graphics card. (Perhaps my card is DirectDraw optimized.)
When I got home last night, I tried the tech demo on my other machine and got slow performance for the entire level just as you did. The strange thing is, that computer is MUCH faster (name just about any part and it's 2 or 4 times faster.)
So I think I know the problem. This is a bit technical... so skip if you want.
Each tile in the screen area get's blitted, one at a time. If you're not familiar with the blitting process, it looks something like this:
1. Lock the destination pixel memory.
2. Copy pixels.
3. Unlock pixel memory.
And this gets repeated for each tile.
From what I've read recently, some video cards are very slow at locking pixel memory.

So what I need to do is write my own (or find an open source) blit function so I can do something like this:
1. Lock the destination pixel memory.
2. Do all the pixel copying required.
3. Unlock.

In the near future, this will take some time to implement. In the long run though, it might allow for me to add special drawing features like alpha blending (partial transparency), because I will have direct control over how it works and be able to optimize it.

The first part is expected, it will change the resolution to 800x600 with 24bit color. Plus it takes a bit to do all the loading. There's no loading progress indicator set up yet.
Do your video card and monitor support 24bit color at this resolution?

title: Fixed!
content:
Well, I'm one forgetful fellow. It's a direct result of some code I originally put in to test and planned to remove later. Unfortunately, the "test" was tuned quite well to my computer, but not for substantially faster or slower machines. So I forgot I did it.
I've fixed it, but in the meantime I was working on other changes and I'll need to finish another feature before updating. Should have it ready Thursday (today or tomorrow, depending on your timezone). Um, within 24 hours.


Technical details follow for anyone who cares:

The way a game keeps things moving smoothly with variable frame rates is by scaling the movement according to how long it is took to draw the last frame.
Well, it's quite possible for one frame to take a LOT more time than others, because something else on the computer suddenly required a lot of the processor, even if just for an instant.
Now, imagine that at 60 fps, something moves 5 pixels per frame. But for just one frame, the fps dropped to say 5. If everything is scaled the same, that object moves 60 pixels in just one frame.
This can be pretty hard for the player to follow, and if it happens a lot, might make you [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sick.gif[/img] or worst of all, you end up with a [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-deadkeenvort.gif[/img] and a [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-mortlol.gif[/img]
So typically, an engine will take the time it took to draw the last frame, and mod it with something reasonable, say 100 milliseconds. The result of this is that even though it might get slightly choppy, the game will play at the same overal speed at as low as 10 fps. (But once you go below this, it actually slows down.)
So I decided to play around with this one day. At first I tried (time mod 255) This was a decent choice. It means the game expects every frame to take between 1 and 255 milliseconds to draw. (255ms = about 4 fps).
Then I thought, what framerate do I want the engine to do? I figured about 30fps would be a good target. For this framerate, a frame can take between 1 and 33.33 milliseconds to draw. Well, since I want to use a bitwise And instead of a mod (much faster), 0x1f is as close to 33 as I can get, so that's what I used.

So what's the problem?
Well, suppose the last frame took 31 milliseconds. (This is about 32 fps.) Well, the engine gets told that it took:
31 mod 31 = 0 milliseconds.
Oops! Now nothing moves!

content:
Those speedier engine changes took a while longer due to a small but difficult to find bug. (Needed to add 31 instead of 32...grr)
Anyway, the download has been updated.
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/keentechdemo10.zip]New Tech Demo[/url]

I didn't think this update needed an all new version, so its the same download location.
Besides making the engine a bit faster, there are a couple other helpful features.

1. Loading status on startup. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
2. Switch in settings.ini for syncronizing the drawing to the screen refresh. Set REFRESH_SYNC to FALSE (all CAPITALS) if you want to see the actual FPS in debug mode. (The red number.) When playing, you'd never want this set to false because it causes "tearing" and the odd jumpy movement.

Have not messed with the jump and pogo height or the depth of tiles.

In case you're wondering, the speedier code was a change to the way the engine finds solid ground. Before it was using an array of true/false values for each tile, so it had to go one pixel at a time to look for a solid spot.
But now each tile has an array of 32 bit values, with each bit replacing the old true/false value above. The benefit of this is that it can check 32 pixels at once. Plus the tiles are exactly 32 pixels wide... convenient, huh?
On my machine, the speed improvement is about 5 fps. Going from about 105 to 110 fps. So this isn't much right now, but there are only two objects using this new feature - the player and the dopey bounder. In an actual level, there can be many more objects, so this will have a huge affect on performance.

title: New demo, more criticism
content:
Just when you thought it was dead, this project arises from the grave. Okay, it was never in the grave, just didn't want to post any new updates until there was something substantially new.
There is now something substantially new. Download the demo here:
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/keentechdemo11.zip]Keen Tech Demo 11[/url] (about 290kb)

A quick description of the demo level:
You start out next to a rotating group of platforms. They aren't moving. Hit the switch to start them.
Above you will see a set of platforms that follow a wandering path. In fact, you'll notice that the two switches that affect these platforms also turn the rain on and off. There are some new tile's I'm working on up here too.
Back from where you start, if you walk to the right, through the hallway, you'll find another set of platforms and two switches. The second switch will have no noticeable affect right now. The first one you come across turns these platforms on. Take a ride on these and you'll end up in a large mostly empty area with a lot of platforms following a long twisty path. You may also notice that you can't get out. That's where the other switch comes in.
At the bottom of this large area, you'll find a lonely switch. Switch it. Nothing may seem to happen at first, the switch will appear to flip back after a second. What happened is that the platforms have been switched to a different path. Now you can take the platforms to get back out of this area. Back in the hallway, the switch that previously had no effect switches these platforms back to their original path. Nifty, huh?
And the level looks a little prettier too, making use of multiple parallaxing tile layers.

For a quick list of the new features:
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/WhatsNew11.txt]WhatsNew11.txt[/url]

There are a few known bugs, those are mentioned here:
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/KnownBugs11.txt]KnownBugs11.txt[/url]

Also, CommanderSpleen mentioned the speed. It is still too fast. But it's convenient for a tech demo to get around and see everything quickly. I'll probably slow it down next time

title: Holy cow!
content:
I guess I'll be releasing a new demo much sooner that originally planned! (probably just an exe to replace the last one)
I was testing this latest demo out and found serious performance problems, but only on my much better machine. (Yeah, go figure, it works slowly on the really fast computer, but nicely on the slower computer...) Well the fix to this problem was not very simple. But it accidentally opened up another change I could make to the graphics system. One that might improve the speed (fps) of the game. I tried it out and ... HOLY COW!!!
Where it was previously running at around 125 fps, it is now running around 300 fps! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-stunned.gif[/img] [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-surprise.gif[/img]
Soon I'll have an update available that will address most of the problems you've pointed out. (I say most because I don't plan to add any more graphics yet. But the movement, ledge climbing, jumping down, etc. should be fixed.)

edit:
I've also noticed that I shouldn't be displaying the fps through the "debug display mode" as I was previously. The way a lot of the debug information is displayed causes a noticable drop in performance (from 300 fps to about 250 fps.) You'll be able to see just the frames per second now, and you shouldn't have to turn the screen refresh sync off.

title: Re: Fixes :)
content:
I think I've fixed all of the bugs found so far. If you have some time, please try out the updated engine. The speed has been "fixed" too, so play with it and tell me if something is too fast or too slow.
Also, you can jump down through platforms as you'd expect. (Although sometimes you wont go all the way through, but thats temporary.)

If you already downloaded the full demo, you can just replace keen.exe with this:
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/Keen_exe.zip]Keen Tech Demo exe only[/url] (about 90kb)
Otherwise, the full download has been updated here:
[url=http://keen.keenx.com/keen/files/keentechdemo11.zip]Keen Tech Demo 11[/url] (still about 290kb)

Also, in addition to the previous debug access, you can see the fps speed of the game by pressing "f". Although technically the game is still limited by your monitor's refresh rate (usually that means 60 fps), the game engine actually does everything it needs to do to draw the screen in less that 1/60 of a second. So the game sits around waiting for the rest of that 1/60 of a second for the monitor to be ready for another screen. The "fps" displayed by the engine is a reflection of how long the engine is actually doing any work, not including the wait time.
